question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule V.1.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
Team participation in the competition is limited to teams from universities or colleges which:
a. Are accredited by their national or regional accrediting body; or
b. Are eligible for accreditation by their national or regional accrediting body
ground_truth:
Open Wheel
Open Wheel vehicles must satisfy all of the following criteria:
a. The top 180° of the wheels/tires must be unobstructed when viewed from vertically
above the wheel.
b. The wheels/tires must be unobstructed when viewed from the side.
c. No part of the vehicle may enter a keep out zone defined by two lines extending
vertically from positions 75 mm in front of and 75 mm aft of, the outer diameter of the
front and rear tires in the side view elevation of the vehicle, with tires steered straight
ahead. This keep out zone will extend laterally from the outside plane of the wheel/tire
to the inboard plane of the wheel/tire.

ground_truth:
Intentional or excessive ground contact of any portion of the vehicle other than the tires will
forfeit a run or an entire dynamic event
The intent is that sliding skirts or other devices that by design, fabrication or as a consequence
of moving, contact the track surface are prohibited and any unintended contact with the
ground which causes damage, or in the opinion of the Dynamic Event Officials could result in
damage to the track, will result in forfeit of a run or an entire dynamic event

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule V.3.1.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
3.1.2 Stability and Control 
a. The vehicle must demonstrate a high degree of stability and control during operation.
This will involve a series of maneuvers at high speeds on a paved track.
The driver will perform a series of high speed slaloms, both forwards and backwards,
and make tight turns at high speeds.  
b. These maneuvers will be evaluated based on the vehicle’s stability and control.  
The vehicle will receive a lower score for each loss of control or failure to complete 
the maneuvers in a satisfactory manner.  
The driver will also be evaluated on his ability to perform these maneuvers in a 
professional and controlled manner.  
The vehicle may not be driven at high speeds on the paved track unless authorized by 
the officials.
```
. • The driver must always have control of the vehicle.  
• The driver must always be able to steer, brake and accelerate the vehicle.  
• The vehicle must always be under control.  
• The driver must always be able to stop or slow the vehicle in a safe manner.
ground_truth:
Officials may disqualify vehicles which do not represent a serious attempt at an operational
suspension system, or which demonstrate handling inappropriate for an autocross circuit.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule V.3.1.5 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
3.1.5 Pressure Testing
a. Each component or assembly that is welded must pass the pressure test as specified in this section.
The test pressure must be high enough to simulate the maximum expected pressure in the area of the weld.
The test pressure must be at least 110% of the yield strength of the material.
b. The weld must be visually inspected for porosity and other defects.
c. The weld must be tested for leaks using a high pressure air gun.
d. Any weld that fails the air gun test must be remade.
e. Any weld that fails the pressure test must be completely remade.
f. The welder must sign a statement of compliance for each weld.
g. The statement of compliance must include the weld number, the material, the weld method and the welder’s signature.  
GR.9.1.4  Correction of Defects  
Defects in work must be corrected before moving on to the next event.  
GR.9.1.5  Second Chance  
Second Chance
ground_truth:
All spherical rod ends and spherical bearings on the suspension and steering must be one of:
• Mounted in double shear
• Captured by having a screw/bolt head or washer with an outside diameter that is larger
than spherical bearing housing inside diameter.

The Primary Structure plus a plane from the top of the Main Hoop to the top of the Front

tube, or monocoque equivalent.

Protection Envelope ends at the rear plane of the Main Hoop

ground_truth:
Triangulation
An arrangement of Frame Members where all members and segments of members between
bends or nodes with Structural tubes form a structure composed entirely of triangles.
a. This is generally required between an upper member and a lower member, both of
which may have multiple segments requiring a diagonal to form multiple triangles.
b. This is also what is meant by “properly triangulated”.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule F.3.5.3 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.

ground_truth:
Aluminum Tubing
a. Minimum Wall Thickness for Aluminum Tubing: Non Welded 2.0 mm
Welded 3.0 mm
b. Non Welded properties for aluminum alloy 6061-T6 for calculations in an SES must be:
Young’s Modulus (E) 69 GPa (10,000 ksi)
Yield Strength (Sy) 240 MPa (34.8 ksi)
Ultimate Strength (Su) 290 MPa (42.1 ksi)
c. Welded properties for aluminum alloy 6061-T6 for calculations in an SES must be:
Yield Strength (Sy) 115 MPa (16.7 ksi)
Ultimate Strength (Su) 175 MPa (25.4 ksi)
d. If welding is used on a regulated aluminum structure, the equivalent yield strength must
be considered in the “as welded” condition for the alloy used unless the team provides
detailed proof that the frame or component has been properly solution heat treated,
artificially aged, and not subject to heating during team manufacturing.
e. If aluminum was solution heat treated and age hardened to increase its strength after
welding, the team must supply evidence as to how the process was performed.
This includes, but is not limited to, the heat treating facility used, the process applied,
and the fixturing used.

Primary Structure Laminate Testing
Teams must build new representative test panels for each ply schedule used in the regulated
regions of the new chassis as a flat panel and perform a 3 point bending test on these panels.
Refer to F.4.3.4
a. Test panels must:
• Measure one of the two options: 138 mm x 500 mm OR 275 mm x 500 mm
• Be supported by a span distance of 400 mm
• Have equal surface area for the top and bottom skin
• Have bare edges, without skin material
b. The SES must include:
• Data from the 3 point bending tests
• Pictures of the test samples
• A picture of the test sample and test setup showing a measurement documenting
the supported span distance used in the SES
c. Test panel results must be used to derive stiffness, yield strength, ultimate strength and
absorbed energy properties by the SES formula and limits for the purpose of calculating
laminate panels equivalency corresponding to Primary Structure regions of the chassis.
d. Test panels must use the thickest core associated with each skin layup.
Designs may use core thickness that is 50% - 100% of the test panel core thickness
associated with each skin layup.
e. Calculation of derived properties must use the part of test data where deflection is 50
mm or less
f. Calculation of absorbed energy must use the integral of force times displacement

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule F.4.3.3 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:

to the dynamic area of the dynamic testing area.
ground_truth:
Comparison Test
Teams must make an equivalent test that will determine any compliance in the test rig and
establish an absorbed energy value of the baseline tubes.
a. The comparison test must use two Side Impact steel tubes (F.3.2.1.e)
b. The steel tubes must be tested to a minimum displacement of 19.0 mm
c. The calculation of absorbed energy must use the integral of force times displacement
from the initiation of load to a displacement of 19.0 mm

e. Be employed by, or work for, any company or organization involved in the competition
ground_truth:
Test Conduct
a. The Laminate test F.4.3.2 and the Comparison test F.4.3.2e must use the same fixture
b. The load applicator used to test any panel/tubes as required in this section F.4.3 must
be:
• Metallic
• Radius 50 mm
c. The load applicator must overhang the test piece to prevent edge loading
d. Any other material must not be placed between the load applicator and the items on test

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule F.4.3.5 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
Team members and students who are not team members, but are working on the vehicle for the team,
including engineers, mechanics, welders, fabricators and machine shop workers, must not start work
until they have signed the FSAE Student Rulebook Accession Form.
ground_truth:
Perimeter Shear Test
a. The Perimeter Shear Test must be completed by measuring the force required to push or
pull a 25 mm diameter flat punch through a flat laminate sample.
b. The sample must:
• Measure 100 mm x 100 mm minimum
• Have core and skin thicknesses identical to those used in the actual application
• Be manufactured using the same materials and processes
c. The fixture must support the entire sample, except for a 32 mm hole aligned coaxially
with the punch.
d. The sample must not be clamped to the fixture
e. The edge of the punch and hole in the fixture may include an optional fillet up to a
maximum radius of 1 mm.
f. The SES must include force and displacement data and photos of the test setup.
g. The first peak in the load-deflection curve must be used to determine the skin shear
strength; this may be less than the minimum force required by F.7.3.3 / F.7.5.5
h. The maximum force recorded must meet the requirements of F.7.3.3 / F.7.5.5

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule F.4.3.6 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
Team members, students, faculty advisors, and other personnel associated with the competition must not receive financial
support from any organization other than the competition organizer.
ground_truth:
Additional Testing
When a laminate schedule(s) are NOT a Quasi-Isotropic Layup (F.4.2):
a. Results from the 3 point bending test will be assigned to the 0 layup direction.
b. The monocoque must have the tested layup direction normal to the cross sections used
for Equivalence in the SES, with allowance for taper of the monocoque normal to the
cross section.
c. All material properties in the weakest direction must be 50% or more of those in the
strongest direction as calculated by the SES.

ground_truth:
Lap Joint Test
The Lap Joint Test measures the force required to pull apart a joint comprised of two laminate
samples that are bonded together.
a. Do two separate pull tests with different orientations of the adhesive joint:
• Parallel to the pull direction, with the adhesive joint in pure shear
• T peel normal to the pull direction, with the adhesive joint in peel
b. The samples used must:
• Have skin thicknesses identical to those used in the actual monocoque
• Be manufactured using the same materials and processes
• Have the same overlap as used in the regulated structure. No scaling is permitted.
c. The force and displacement data and photos of the test setup must be included in the
SES.
d. The shear strength of the bond must be more than the UTS of the skin

ground_truth:
If a bent tube (or member consisting of multiple tubes that are not in a line) is used anywhere
in the Primary Structure other than the Roll Hoops (see F.5.6.2), an additional tube must be
attached to support it.
a. The support tube attachment point must be at the position along the bent tube where it
deviates farthest from a straight line connecting both ends
b. The support tube must terminate at a node of the chassis
c. The support tube for any bent tube (other than the Upper Side Impact Member or
Shoulder Harness Mounting Bar) must be:
• The same diameter and thickness as the bent tube
• Angled no more than 30° from the plane of the bent tube

ground_truth:
Roll Hoop and Driver Position
When seated normally and restrained by the Driver Restraint System, the helmet of a 95th
percentile male (see V.2.1.1) and all of the team’s drivers must:
a. Be a minimum of 50 mm from the straight line drawn from the top of the Main Hoop to
the top of the Front Hoop.
b. Be a minimum of 50 mm from the straight line drawn from the top of the Main Hoop to
the lower end of the Main Hoop Bracing if the bracing extends rearwards.
c. Be no further rearwards than the rear surface of the Main Hoop if the Main Hoop Bracing
extends forwards.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule F.5.6.4 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:

events.
ground_truth:
Driver Template
A two dimensional template used to represent the 95th percentile male is made to the
following dimensions (see figure below):
• A circle of diameter 200 mm will represent the hips and buttocks.
• A circle of diameter 200 mm will represent the shoulder/cervical region.
• A circle of diameter 300 mm will represent the head (with helmet).
• A straight line measuring 490 mm will connect the centers of the two 200 mm circles.
• A straight line measuring 280 mm will connect the centers of the upper 200 mm circle
and the 300 mm head circle.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule F.5.6.5 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.

a. Not drive any vehicle on the dynamic testing area unless authorized by the Dynamic Testing
Organizer.
b. Use the pedestrian path provided when entering or leaving the dynamic testing area.
c. Wear the required safety equipment as specified in the FSAE Regulation.
d. Follow all instructions given by the Dynamic Testing Organizer or other authorized personnel.
e. Not touch any dynamic testing equipment or instruments without first being given permission by the
Dynamic Testing Organizer.
f. Not make any measurements or recordings without first being given permission by the Dynamic
Testing Organizer.
g. Not drive any vehicle on the dynamic testing area unless given permission by the Dynamic Testing
Organizer.
ground_truth:
Driver Template Position
The Driver Template will be positioned as follows:
• The seat will be adjusted to the rearmost position
• The pedals will be placed in the most forward position
• The bottom 200 mm circle will be placed on the seat bottom where the distance
between the center of this circle and the rearmost face of the pedals is no less than 915
mm
• The middle 200 mm circle, representing the shoulders, will be positioned on the seat
back
• The upper 300 mm circle will be positioned no more than 25 mm away from the head
restraint (where the driver’s helmet would normally be located while driving)

ground_truth:
The Front Bulkhead must be supported back to the Front Hoop by a minimum of three Frame
Members on each side of the vehicle; an upper member; lower member and diagonal brace to
provide Triangulation.
a. The upper support member must be attached 50 mm or less from the top surface of the
Front Bulkhead, and attach to the Front Hoop inside a zone extending 100 mm above
and 50 mm below the Upper Side Impact member.
b. If the upper support member is further than 100 mm above the Upper Side Impact
member, then properly Triangulated bracing is required to transfer load to the Main
Hoop by one of:
• the Upper Side Impact member
• an additional member transmitting load from the junction of the Upper Support
Member with the Front Hoop
c. The lower support member must be attached to the base of the Front Bulkhead and the
base of the Front Hoop.
d. The diagonal brace must properly Triangulate the upper and lower support members

ground_truth:
The lower end of the Main Hoop Braces must be supported back to the Main Hoop by a
minimum of two Frame Members on each side of the vehicle: an upper member and a lower
member in a properly Triangulated configuration.
a. The upper support member must attach to the node where the upper Side Impact
Member attaches to the Main Hoop.
b. The lower support member must attach to the node where the lower Side Impact
Member attaches to the Main Hoop.
c. Each of the above members may be multiple or bent tubes provided the requirements of
F.5.2 are met.
d. Examples of acceptable configurations of members may be found in the SES.

ground_truth:
The outside profile requirement of the Anti Intrusion Plate depends on the method of
attachment to the Front Bulkhead:
a. Welded joints: the profile must align with or be more than the centerline of the Front
Bulkhead tubes on all sides
b. Bolted joints, bonding, laminating: the profile must align with or be more than the
outside dimensions of the Front Bulkhead around the entire periphery

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule F.8.2.3 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
Team members and suppliers must not have worked on the project for more than 6 months preceding the date of the 
competition event or for 12 months prior to the start of the competition event.
ground_truth:
Attachment of the Anti Intrusion Plate directly to the Front Bulkhead must be documented in
the team’s SES submission. The accepted methods of attachment are:
a. Welding
• All weld lengths must be 25 mm or longer
• If interrupted, the weld/space ratio must be 1:1 or higher
b. Bolted joints
• Using no less than eight 8 mm or 5/16” minimum diameter Critical Fasteners, T.8.2.
• The distance between any two bolt centers must be 50 mm minimum.
• Each bolt attachment must have pullout, tearout and bending capabilities of 15 kN
c. Bonding
• The Front Bulkhead must have no openings
• The entire surface of the Anti Intrusion Plate must be bonded, with shear and peel
strength higher than 120 kN
d. Laminating
• The Anti Intrusion Plate must be in front of the outer skin of the Front Bulkhead
• The lamination must fully enclose the Anti Intrusion Plate and have shear capability
higher than 120 kN

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule F.8.3.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.

minimum Impact Attenuator area

• Test data is valid for only one Competition Year
b. Laminate material testing under F.4.3.2 and F.4.3.5 and calculations of 3 point bending
and perimeter shear

ground_truth:
The Custom Impact Attenuator must meet the following:
a. Length 200 mm or more, with its length oriented along the fore/aft axis of the Chassis.
b. Minimum height 100 mm (perpendicular to the ground) and minimum width 200 mm
(parallel to the ground) for a minimum distance of 200 mm forward of the Front
Bulkhead.
c. Segmented foam attenuators must have all segments bonded together to prevent sliding
or parallelogramming.
d. Honeycomb attenuators made of multiple segments must have a continuous panel
between each segment.

ground_truth:

the Standard Honeycomb Impact Attenuator, and then one of the two must be met:
a. The Front Bulkhead must include an additional support that is a diagonal or X-brace that
meets F.3.2.1.b or Equivalent (integral or attached) for Monocoque bulkheads F.2.3.1
• The structure must go across the entire Front Bulkhead opening on the diagonal
• Attachment points at both ends must carry a minimum load of 30 kN in any
direction
b. Physical testing per F.8.8.6 and F.8.8.7 must be performed to prove that the Anti
Intrusion Plate does not permanently deflect more than 25 mm.

ground_truth:
Impact Attenuator Test Setup
a. During any test, the Impact Attenuator must be attached to the Anti Intrusion Plate using
the intended vehicle attachment method.
b. The Impact Attenuator Assembly must be attached to a structurally representative
section of the intended chassis.
The test fixture must have equivalent strength and stiffness to a baseline front bulkhead.
A solid block of material in the shape of the front bulkhead is not “structurally
representative”.
c. There must be 50 mm minimum clearance rearwards of the Anti Intrusion Plate to the
test fixture.
d. No part of the Anti Intrusion Plate may permanently deflect more than 25 mm beyond
the position of the Anti Intrusion Plate before the test.
The 25 mm spacing represents the front bulkhead support and insures that the plate does not
intrude excessively into the cockpit.

ground_truth:
Test Conduct
a. Composite Impact Attenuators must be Dynamic Tested.
Other Impact Attenuator constructions may be Dynamic Tested or Quasi-Static Tested
b. Dynamic Testing (sled, pendulum, drop tower, etc.) of the Impact Attenuator must be
conducted at a dedicated test facility. This facility may be part of the University, but must
be supervised by professional staff or the University faculty. Teams must not construct
their own dynamic test apparatus.
c. Quasi-Static Testing may be performed by teams using their University’s
facilities/equipment, but teams are advised to exercise due care when performing all
tests.

ground_truth:
Test Analysis
a. When using acceleration data from the dynamic test, the average deceleration must be
calculated based on the raw unfiltered data.
b. If peaks above the 40 g limit are present in the data, a Channel Filter Class (CFC) 60
(100Hz) filter per SAE Recommended Practice J211 “Instrumentation for Impact Test”, or
a 100 Hz, 3rd order, low pass Butterworth (-3dB at 100 Hz) filter may be applied.

ground_truth:
The accepted methods of joining walls to walls and walls to floor are:
a. Welding
• Welds may be continuous or interrupted.
• If interrupted, the weld/space ratio must be 1:1 or higher
• All weld lengths must be more than 25 mm
b. Fasteners
Combined strength of the fasteners must be Equivalent to the strength of the welded
joint ( F.10.2.3.a above )
c. Bonding
• Bonding must meet F.5.5
• Strength of the bonded joint must be Equivalent to the strength of the welded joint
( F.10.2.3.a above )
• Bonds must run the entire length of the joint

recommended.

ground_truth:
Accumulator Attachment – Corner Attachments
a. Eight or more attachments are required for any configuration.
• One attachment for each corner of a rectangular structure of multiple Accumulator
Segments
• More than the minimum number of fasteners may be required for non rectangular
arrangements
Examples: If not filled in with additional structure, an extruded L shape would require
attachments at 10 convex corners (the corners at the inside of the L are not convex);
an extruded hexagon would require 12 attachments
b. The mechanical connections at each corner must be 50 mm or less from the corner of
the Segment
c. Each attachment point must be able to withstand a Test Load equal to 1/4 of total mass
of the container accelerating at 40 g

ground_truth:
Accumulator Attachment – All Types
a. Every fastener must withstand the Test Load in pure shear, using the minor diameter if
any threads are in shear
b. Every Accumulator bracket, chassis bracket, or monocoque attachment point must
withstand the Test Load in bending, in pure tearout, pure pullout, pure weld shear if
welded, and pure bond shear and pure bond tensile if bonded.
c. Monocoque attachment points must meet F.7.8.8
d. Fasteners must be spaced minimum 50 mm apart to be counted as separate attachment
points

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule F.11.2.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction: The vehicle must be 1400 mm wide maximum.
ground_truth:
Side Impact Protection
a. All Accumulator Containers must be protected from side impact by structure Equivalent
to Side Impact Structure (F.6.4, F.7.5)
The Accumulator Container must not be part of the Equivalent structure.
b. Accumulator Container side impact protection must go to a minimum height that is the
lower of the two:
• The height of the Upper Side Impact Structure
• The top of the Accumulator Container at that point
c. Tractive System components other than Accumulator Containers in a position below 350
mm from the ground must be protected from side impact by structure that meets F.5.16
Component Protection

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule F.11.2.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
30 minutes before the start of the dynamic test event, the vehicle must be presented for Inspection,
unlocked and with all keys present.
ground_truth:
Rear Impact Protection
a. All Accumulator Containers must be protected from rear impact:
• When the rear impact structure is 100 mm or less from an Accumulator Container,
the structure must be Equivalent to Side Impact Structure (F.6.4, F.7.5)
• When the rear impact structure is more than 100 mm from an Accumulator
Container, the structure must meet F.5.16 Component Protection
• The Accumulator Container must not be part of the Equivalent structure.
b. The Rear Impact Protection for the Accumulator Container must:
• Go to the Upper Side Impact Height at minimum
• Have a structural and triangulated load path from the top of the Rear Impact
Protection to the Upper Side Impact Structure F.6.4, F.7.5 at the Main Hoop
• Have a structural and triangulated load path from the bottom of the Rear Impact
Protection to the Lower Side Impact Structure F.6.4, F.7.5 at the Main Hoop
c. Other Tractive System components in a position below 350 mm from the ground must be
protected from rear impact by structure meeting F.5.16 Component Protection
d. Differential mounts or a plate behind upper and lower rear impact tubes may be used as
Rear Impact Protection.
If used, the mounts or plate must be 25 mm or more larger at both the top and bottom
of the upper and lower tubes

Accelerator Pedal
a. An Accelerator Pedal must control the Powertrain output
b. Pedal Travel is the percent of travel from a fully released position to a fully applied
position. 0% is fully released and 100% is fully applied.

• Return to 0% Pedal Travel when not pushed
• Have a positive stop to prevent any cable, actuation system or sensor from damage
or overstress

ground_truth:
The design must address all three types of heat transfer between the heat source (examples
include but are not limited to: exhaust pipe, coolant hose/tube, Accumulator Container) and
the panel that the driver could contact (seat or floor):
a. Conduction Isolation by one of the following:
• No direct contact between the heat source and the panel
• A heat resistant, conduction isolation material with a minimum thickness of 8 mm
between the heat source and the panel
b. Convection Isolation by a minimum air gap of 25 mm between the heat source and the
panel
c. Radiation Isolation by one of the following:
• A solid metal heat shield with a minimum thickness of 0.4 mm
• Reflective foil or tape when combined with conduction insulation

ground_truth:
Harness Definitions
a. 5 Point Harness – consists of two Lap Belts, two Shoulder Belts and one Anti-Submarine
Belt.
b. 6 Point Harness – consists of two Lap Belts, two Shoulder Belts and two leg or Anti-
Submarine Belts.
c. 7 Point Harness – consists of two Lap Belts, two Shoulder Belts, two leg or Anti-
Submarine Belts and a negative g or Z Belt.
d. Upright Driving Position - with a seat back angled at 30° or less from the vertical as
measured along the line joining the two 200 mm circles of the template of the 95th
percentile male as defined in F.5.6.4 and positioned per F.5.6.5
e. Reclined Driving Position - with a seat back angled at more than 30° from the vertical as
measured along the line joining the two 200 mm circles of the template of the 95th
percentile male as defined in F.5.6.4 and positioned per F.5.6.5
f. Chest to Groin Line - the straight line that in side view follows the line of the Shoulder
Belts from the chest to the release buckle.

ground_truth:
Each tab or bracket to which any part of the Harness is attached must:
a. Support a minimum load in pullout and tearout before failure of:
• If one belt is attached to the tab or bracket 15 kN
• If two belts are attached to the tab or bracket 30 kN
b. Be 1.6 mm minimum thickness
c. Not be in bending when the attached part of the Harness is put under load
d. Not cause abrasion to the belt webbing

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule T.2.4.4 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
Team members may not work on any vehicle task for any team at any competition event, other than the 
competition event for which the vehicle has been entered.
ground_truth:
Attachment of tabs or brackets must meet the following:
a. Where brackets are fastened to the chassis, no less than two 6 mm or 1/4” minimum
diameter Critical Fasteners, see T.8.2 or stronger must be used to attach the bracket to
the chassis.
b. Where a single shear tab is welded to the chassis, the tab to tube welding must be on
both sides of the base of the tab.
Double shear attachments are preferred. Tabs and brackets for double shear mounts should
be welded on both sides.

ground_truth:
The Anti-Submarine Belts of a 6 point harness must be mounted in one of the following ways:
a. With the belts going vertically down from the groin, or with an Anti-Submarine Belt Side
View Angle up to 20° rearwards. The Anti-Submarine Belt Mount Spacing should be
approximately 100 mm apart.
b. With the Anti-Submarine Belt Mounting Points on the Primary Structure at or near the
Lap Belt anchorages, the driver sitting on the Anti-Submarine Belts, and the belts coming
up around the groin to the release buckle.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule T.2.7.3 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.

Mounting Point(s) without touching any hole in the seat or any other intermediate structure
until they reach:
a. The release buckle for the 5 Point Harness mounting per T.2.7.1
b. The first point where the belt touches the driver’s body for the 6 Point Harness mounting
per T.2.7.2

The belt must not be able to touch the ground.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule T.2.8.5 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction: Team members, students, faculty advisors, alumni, sponsors, donors and other individuals associated with the competition must not receive preferential treatment or special consideration.
ground_truth:
For all drivers, the Head Restraint must be located and adjusted where:
a. The Head Restraint is no more than 25 mm away from the back of the driver’s helmet,
with the driver in their normal driving position.
b. The contact point of the back of the driver’s helmet on the Head Restraint is no less than
50 mm from any edge of the Head Restraint.

configurations require prior approval.

ground_truth:
The BSE must be able to be checked during Technical Inspection by having one of:
• A separate detachable connector(s) for any BSE signal(s) to the main ECU without
affecting any other connections
• An inline switchable breakout box available that allows disconnection of each BSE
signal(s) to the main ECU without affecting any other connections

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule T.4.3.3 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
Team Members: The following people are considered team members: Accession date to the competition site 
where the vehicle is placed, and anytime at or near the Dynamic Area where the vehicle is operated.
ground_truth:
The BSE or switch signals must be sent directly to a controller using an analogue signal or via a
digital data transmission bus such as CAN or FlexRay
Any failure of the BSE or BSE wiring that persists more than 100 msec must be detectable by
the controller and treated like an implausibility and power to the (IC) electronic throttle / (EV)
Motor(s) must be immediately stopped completely.
(EV only) It is not necessary to completely deactivate the Tractive System, the motor
controller(s) stopping power to the motor(s) is sufficient.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule T.4.3.4 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
Team members and students who work on the vehicle must not be employed by any organization that is 
associated with the competition and must not have any contract or agreement with such an organization.
ground_truth:
When an analogue signal is used, the BSE sensors will be considered to have failed when they
achieve an open circuit or short circuit condition which generates a signal outside of the
normal operating range, for example <0.5 V or >4.5 V.
The circuitry used to evaluate the sensor must use pull down or pull up resistors to ensure
that open circuit signals result in a failure being detected.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule T.4.3.5 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
Team members and suppliers must not have any direct or indirect association with any competition
organizer, judge, inspector, controller, inspector of compliance or inspector of dynamic performance
for the duration of the competition.
ground_truth:
When any kind of digital data transmission is used to transmit the BSE signal:
a. The ETC Systems Form must contain a detailed description of all the potential failure
modes that can occur, the strategy that is used to detect these failures and the tests that
have been conducted to prove that the detection strategy works.
b. The failures modes must include but are not limited to the failure of the sensor, sensor
signals being out of range, corruption of the message and loss of messages and the
associated time outs.
c. In all cases a sensor failure must immediately shutdown power to the motor(s).

d. Salaries paid to individuals performing work directly related to the design of vehicles for the competition (such as

tube to the ground

wheels do not touch the ground when they are in full rebound

ground_truth:
Arm Restraints
a. Arm restraints must be worn in a way that the driver can release them and exit the
vehicle unassisted regardless of the vehicle’s position.
b. Arm restraints must be commercially manufactured. Arm restraints certified to SFI Spec
3.3 and labeled as such meet this requirement.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.1.1.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction: The vehicle must be a four wheel drive vehicle.
ground_truth:
The engine(s) used to power the vehicle must:
a. Be a piston engine(s) using a four stroke primary heat cycle
b. Have a total combined displacement less than or equal to 710 cc per cycle.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.1.1.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction: The vehicle must be a four wheel drive vehicle.
ground_truth:
Hybrid powertrains, such as those using electric motors running off stored energy, are
prohibited.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.1.1.3 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction: The vehicle must be a single vehicle, not a composite of multiple vehicles.
ground_truth:
All waste/rejected heat from the primary heat cycle may be used. The method of conversion is
not limited to the four stroke cycle.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.1.1.4 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction: The vehicle must be a four wheel drive vehicle with a maximum of two wheels inboard of the primary drive axle.
ground_truth: The engine may be modified within the restrictions of the rules.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.1.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction: The vehicle must be a four wheel drive vehicle.
ground_truth:
Air Intake and Fuel System Location
All parts of the engine air system and fuel control, delivery and storage systems (including the
throttle or carburetor, and the complete air intake system, including the air cleaner and any
air boxes) must lie inside the Tire Surface Envelope F.1.14

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.2.2.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction: The vehicle must be a four wheel drive vehicle.
ground_truth:
Any portion of the air intake system that is less than 350 mm above the ground must be
shielded from side or rear impacts by structure built per F.6.4 / F.7.5 as applicable.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.2.3.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction: The vehicle must be capable of being driven by a person.
ground_truth:
The intake manifold must be securely attached to the engine block or cylinder head with
brackets and mechanical fasteners.
• Hose clamps, plastic ties, or safety wires do not meet this requirement.
• The use of rubber bushings or hose is acceptable for creating and sealing air passages,
but is not a structural attachment.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.2.3.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
Team Members: The following individuals are considered Team Members:
a. Team Members who are employed by the same organization
b. Students who have a contract to perform work as part of a coop or internship program
c. Individuals who have a contract to perform work as consultants
d. Individuals who are paid to teach or speak at FSAE events
e. Volunteers who work on site at FSAE events
f. Individuals who are paid to work on a project at a FSAE event
g. Volunteers who work on a project at a FSAE event
ground_truth:
Threaded fasteners used to secure and/or seal the intake manifold must have a Positive
Locking Mechanism, see T.8.3.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.2.3.3 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
The vehicle must be driven by the driver standing normally at the steering wheel, with his or her feet
positioned normally on the pedals.
ground_truth:
Intake systems with significant mass or cantilever from the cylinder head must be supported
to prevent stress to the intake system.
a. Supports to the engine must be rigid.
b. Supports to the Chassis must incorporate some isolation to allow for engine movement
and chassis flex.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.2.4.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction: The vehicle must be a single unit, i.e. integrated, without easily separable parts.
ground_truth:
All airflow to the engine(s) must pass through a single circular restrictor placed in the intake
system.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.2.4.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction: The vehicle must be able to pass through a 25 mm diameter opening unobstructed.
ground_truth:
The only allowed sequence of components are the following:
a. For naturally aspirated engines, the sequence must be: throttle body, restrictor, and
engine.
b. For turbocharged or supercharged engines, the sequence must be: restrictor,
compressor, throttle body, engine.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.2.4.3 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
Team members and students who work on the vehicle must not directly work for the same 
competition organizer for 12 months after the competition.
ground_truth:
The maximum restrictor diameters at any time during the competition are:
a. Gasoline fueled vehicles 20.0 mm
b. E85 fueled vehicles 19.0 mm

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.2.4.4 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction: The vehicle must be capable of being driven on a paved road.
ground_truth: The restrictor must be located to facilitate measurement during Technical Inspection

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.2.4.5 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
Team members, students, faculty advisors, alumni, donors, industry sponsors, and other individuals associated with the competition must not receive any
compensation for activities related to the competition other than:
a. Reimbursement for actual, documented out of pocket expenses
b. Stipends to cover living expenses while at the competition site (see F.9.3)
c. Wages for work performed at the competition site (see F.9.4)
d. Travel expenses (see F.9.2)
ground_truth: The circular restricting cross section must NOT be movable or flexible in any way

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.2.4.6 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
Team members, students, faculty advisors, alumni, and other individuals associated with the competition must not receive compensation, other than
reimbursement of actual, documented expenses, for any work performed for the competition.
ground_truth: The restrictor must not be part of the movable portion of a barrel throttle body.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.2.5.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
The vehicle must be a four wheel drive vehicle with a crankshaft located in the lowest
position of the vehicle, with the engine in the lowest position of the vehicle, with the engine
behind the front axle.
ground_truth:
The intake air may be cooled with an intercooler (a charge air cooler).
a. It must be located downstream of the throttle body
b. Only ambient air may be used to remove heat from the intercooler system
c. Air to air and water to air intercoolers are permitted
d. The coolant of a water to air intercooler system must meet T.5.4.1

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.2.5.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction: The vehicle must be a single, integrated vehicle consisting of a chassis and a main body.
ground_truth:
If pop-off valves, recirculation valves, or heat exchangers (intercoolers) are used, they must be
positioned in the intake system as shown in IC.2.4.2.b

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.2.5.3 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
Team Members and Accident Report Information
a. Team Members must be listed in the order of their involvement in the accident.
b. The Team Member’s name, contact information and relationship to the team (student, mentor,
professional, volunteer) must be provided.
c. The Accident Report must include:
i. A description of the accident
ii. The date of the accident
iii. The location of the accident
iv. The time of the accident
v. A description of the vehicle involved in the accident
vi. Any other relevant information
vii. Photographs of the accident and the vehicle involved in the accident
viii. Sketches or diagrams of the accident and the vehicle involved in the accident
ix. Any other relevant data
x. Any other relevant information
The Accident Report must be submitted within 30 days of the accident.  
GR.8.5.4  Submission and Evaluation  
GR.8.5.4.1  Each team may submit a protest to the organizer at the time of the protest period 
identified in these regulations.  The protest period will
ground_truth:
Plenums must not be located anywhere upstream of the throttle body
For the purpose of definition, a plenum is any tank or volume that is a significant enlargement
of the normal intake runner system. Teams may submit their designs via a Rules Question for
review prior to competition if the legality of their proposed system is in doubt.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.2.5.4 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction: Team members may not participate in any capacity for any competition where their team is entered.
ground_truth:
The maximum allowable area of the inner diameter of the intake runner system between the
restrictor and throttle body is 2825 mm2

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.2.6 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction: The vehicle must be able to move under its own power without the need for manual pushing.
ground_truth:
Connections to Intake
Any crankcase or engine lubrication vent lines routed to the intake system must be connected
upstream of the intake system restrictor.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.3.1.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction: The vehicle must be a four wheel drive vehicle with a maximum of two wheels in the front and two in the rear.
ground_truth:
The vehicle must have a carburetor or throttle body.
a. The carburetor or throttle body may be of any size or design.
b. Boosted applications must not use carburetors.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.3.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
The vehicle must be driven in all modes (forward, reverse, and steering) using the driver seated in the driver
position with their feet flat on the pedals.
ground_truth:
Throttle Actuation Method
The throttle may be actuated:
a. Mechanically by a cable or rod system IC.3.3
b. By Electronic Throttle Control IC.4

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.3.3.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
The vehicle must be a four wheel drive vehicle with a powertrain that is mechanically linked to all four
wheels.
ground_truth:
The throttle cable or rod must:
a. Have smooth operation
b. Have no possibility of binding or sticking
c. Be minimum 50 mm from any exhaust system component and out of the exhaust stream
d. Be protected from being bent or kinked by the driver’s foot when it is operated by the
driver or when the driver enters or exits the vehicle

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.3.3.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
Team members and suppliers must not have any affiliation with any automotive industry
companies for one year before the event and for one year after the event.
ground_truth:
The throttle actuation system must use two or more return springs located at the throttle
body.
Throttle Position Sensors (TPS) are NOT acceptable as return springs

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.3.3.3 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction: The vehicle must be a four wheel drive vehicle.
ground_truth:
Failure of any component of the throttle system must not prevent the throttle returning to
the closed position.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.4 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
The vehicle must be driven to the dynamic testing area under power using the Dynamic
Testing Path.
ground_truth:
ELECTRONIC THROTTLE CONTROL
This section IC.4 applies only when Electronic Throttle Control is used
An Electronic Throttle Control (ETC) system may be used. This is a device or system which
may change the engine throttle setting based on various inputs.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.4.1.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction: The vehicle must be a single vehicle, meaning a single integrated vehicle, not a collection of multiple vehicles.
ground_truth: The electronic throttle must automatically close (return to idle) when power is removed.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.4.1.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
The vehicle must be a four wheel drive vehicle with a powertrain that includes a mechanism for shifting
the drive between the front and rear wheels.
ground_truth:
The electronic throttle must use minimum two sources of energy capable of returning the
throttle to the idle position.
a. One of the sources may be the device (such as a DC motor) that normally actuates the
throttle
b. The other device(s) must be a throttle return spring that can return the throttle to the
idle position if loss of actuator power occurs.
c. Springs in the TPS are not acceptable throttle return springs

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.4.1.3 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction: The vehicle must be driven by the driver standing or sitting in the driver’s seat.
ground_truth:
The ETC system may blip the throttle during downshifts when proven that unintended
acceleration can be avoided. The functional analysis must be documented in the ETC Systems
Form

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.4.2.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
Team Members and Accidents
     (IC.4.2.1) A Team Member who, while participating in the competition, is involved in an on - track accident, 
must be immediately removed from the competition.
ground_truth:
An ETC system that is commercially available, but does not comply with the regulations, may
be used, if approved prior to the event.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.4.2.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
Team members, students, faculty advisors, alumni, donors, and other individuals associated with the competition must not receive financial
assistance from the competition organizer or from any other source.
ground_truth:
To obtain approval, submit a Rules Question which includes:
• Which ETC system the team is seeking approval to use.
• The specific ETC rule(s) that the commercial system deviates from.
• Sufficient technical details of these deviations to determine the acceptability of the
commercial system.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.4.3.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction: The vehicle must be a four wheel drive vehicle.
ground_truth:
The ETC Notice of Intent:
• Must be submitted to inform the organizer of the intent to run ETC
• May be used to screen which teams are allowed to use ETC

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.4.3.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
Team members and suppliers must not visit the Facility or receive information about the Vehicle
     from any source during the period beginning at the start of the Technical Inspection for the
competition in which the vehicle is entered and ending 30 days later.
     “Competition” for purposes of this rule means:
a. Any competition organized or sanctioned by the FSAE International Organization
b. Any competition where the vehicles are judged or timed against the clock
c. Any other competition related to vehicle design where the vehicles are presented to the public
or judged on design merits.    
D.3.3  Submission Penalties  
Submission penalties apply for violations of the Submission requirements for any part of the competition.  
D.3.4  Protest Period  
Protests concerning any aspect of the competition must be filed in the protest period provided by the 
Event Organizer.  
D.3.5  Decision on Protests  
Protests are decided by the organizer or a protest committee, with no (re) inspect the vehicle or 
review already completed.
ground_truth: The ETC Systems Form must be submitted in order to use ETC

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.4.3.3 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
Team members and suppliers must not have any direct or indirect association with any
competition teams for which they work or supply goods or services for any competition
period longer than 12 months.
ground_truth:
Submit the ETC Notice of Intent and ETC Systems Form as given in section DR - Document
Requirements

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.4.3.4 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
Team members may work on the vehicle at the Facility only if:
a. The vehicle is not operational
b. The vehicle is being tested
c. The vehicle is being fabricated or repaired
d. The vehicle is being inspected
e. The vehicle is being stored
ground_truth: Late or non submission will prevent use of ETC, see DR.3.4.1

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.4.4.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction: The vehicle must be operated from the driver’s seat in the cockpit.
ground_truth:
The TPS must measure the position of the throttle or the throttle actuator.
Throttle position is defined as percent of travel from fully closed to wide open where 0% is
fully closed and 100% is fully open.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.4.4.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
Team members, students, faculty advisors, alumni, and other individuals associated with the competition must not receive financial
assistance to participate in the competition from any source other than the competition organizer.
ground_truth:
Two or more separate sensors must be used as TPSs. The TPSs may share the same supply and
reference lines only if effects of supply and/or reference line voltage offsets can be detected.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.4.4.3 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
Team members, students, faculty advisors, alumni, donors, and other individuals associated with the competition
     must not receive compensation for their work on the competition, except as specified in the rules.
     “Compensation” includes salaries, wages, honorariums and other forms of payment.
ground_truth:
Implausibility is defined as a deviation of more than 10% throttle position between the
sensors or other failure as defined in Section IC.4. Use of values larger than 10% may be
considered on a case by case basis and require justification in the ETC Systems Form

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.4.4.4 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
Team members and students who work on the vehicle must not be employed by the same organization for which 
the vehicle is prepared, for more than 12 months before the first event of the calendar year in which 
the vehicle is entered.
ground_truth:
If an Implausibility occurs between the values of the two TPSs and persists for more than 100
msec, the power to the electronic throttle must be immediately shut down.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.4.4.5 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction: The vehicle must be operated with the driver standing inside the cockpit normal to the centerline of the vehicle.
ground_truth:
If three sensors are used, then in the case of a TPS failure, any two TPSs that agree within 10%
throttle position may be used to define the throttle position target and the 3rd TPS may be
ignored.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.4.4.6 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction: Team members, students, faculty advisors, and industry sponsors/employees are not allowed on the dynamic testing area unless specifically invited by the Dynamic Testing Area Staff.
ground_truth:
Each TPS must be able to be checked during Technical Inspection by having one of:
a. A separate detachable connector(s) for any TPS signal(s) to the main ECU without
affecting any other connections
b. An inline switchable breakout box available that allows disconnection of each TPS
signal(s) to the main ECU without affecting any other connections

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.4.4.7 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
Team members may not work on any vehicle for more than 4 hours per day, or more than 20 hours per week on the
competition site.
ground_truth:
The TPS signals must be sent directly to the throttle controller using an analogue signal or via
a digital data transmission bus such as CAN or FlexRay. Any failure of the TPSs or TPS wiring
must be detectable by the controller and must be treated like Implausibility.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.4.4.8 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
Team Members and Supporters
     (IC.4.4.1) Individuals who are Team Members or Supporters must not visit the Facility where the vehicle is
constructed or where vehicle tear down/reconstruction occurs, unless authorized by the Facility
Personnel.  
a. If authorized, the Team Member or Supporter must:
• Wear approved livery for the competition.
• Be accompanied by at least two (2) Team Members who are designated as the only escorts for that
individual.  
b. Individuals who are not Team Members or Supporters must not be used as escorts.
ground_truth:
When an analogue signal is used, the TPSs will be considered to have failed when they achieve
an open circuit or short circuit condition which generates a signal outside of the normal
operating range, for example <0.5 V or >4.5 V.
The circuitry used to evaluate the sensor must use pull down or pull up resistors to ensure
that open circuit signals result in a failure being detected.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.4.4.9 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
Team members, students, faculty advisors, and industry sponsors must not work on the vehicle
     together at the same place and at the same time.
ground_truth:
When any kind of digital data transmission is used to transmit the TPS signal,
a. The ETC Systems Form must contain a detailed description of all the potential failure
modes that can occur, the strategy that is used to detect these failures and the tests that
have been conducted to prove that the detection strategy works.
b. The failures to be considered must include but are not limited to the failure of the TPS,
TPS signals being out of range, corruption of the message and loss of messages and the
associated time outs.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.4.5 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction: Team members and Faculty Advisors who are present in the paddock must wear the uniform provided by the organizer.
ground_truth:
Accelerator Pedal Position Sensor - APPS
Refer to T.4.2 for specific requirements of the APPS

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.4.6 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
Team Members: Team members must be students, faculty or staff of the participating university.
     Individual Participation: Each university may participate with multiple teams.
     Team Composition: Each team must have at least 12  members, including:
a. Technical Lead
b. Structural Engineer
c. Structural Analyst
d. Fabrication Lead
e. Fabrication Technician
f. Manufacturing Engineer
g. Manufacturing Technician
h. Prototype Manager
i. Prototype Technician 
j. Driver
k. Scorekeeper
l. Faculty Advisor (optional)
The multiple teams from same university must be clearly identified on the schedule.  
Formation of multiple teams is allowed if the multiple teams have people and resources 
sufficient to accomplish the task.   
Each team must be identified by a unique alphanumeric code, at least 4 digits long.   
 
GR.1.3  Electrical System Limitations  
GR.1.3.1  The engine must start with the engine control system  selected and the starter 
disabled
ground_truth:
Brake System Encoder - BSE
Refer to T.4.3 for specific requirements of the BSE

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.4.7.1 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction: The vehicle must be operated from the driver’s seat in the cockpit.
ground_truth:
Brakes and Throttle Position
a. The power to the electronic throttle must be shut down if the mechanical brakes are
actuated and the TPS signals that the throttle is open by more than a permitted amount
for more than one second.
b. An interval of one second is allowed for the throttle to close (return to idle). Failure to
achieve this in the required interval must result in immediate shut down of fuel flow and
the ignition system.
c. The permitted relationship between BSE and TPS may be defined by the team using a
table. This functionality must be demonstrated at Technical Inspection.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule IC.4.7.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
Team Members who are not students:  
• Are not allowed to work on the vehicle at any competition site  
• Are not allowed to be in the paddock at any competition site  
• May attend at their own risk  
    AD.3.2  Accreditation  
The vehicle will be credited with the Accreditation of the Faculty Advisor’s university , based 
on the scope of the engineering project, as defined in AD.1.2.  
AD.3.3  Student Participation  
Students participating on the project must be currently enrolled in an undergraduate or graduate 
program at the student’s university.

AD.9.1  Grading and Scoring  
AD.9.1.1  All entries for a particular competition will be evaluated in three or four teams, depending on the 
event, and the team that scores highest will be declared the winner
ground_truth:
Throttle Position vs Target
a. The power to the electronic throttle must be immediately shut down, if throttle position
differs by more than 10% from the expected target TPS position for more than one
second.
b. An interval of one second is allowed for the difference to reduce to less than 10%, failure
to achieve this in the required interval must result in immediate shut down of fuel flow
and the ignition system.
c. An error in TPS position and the resultant system shutdown must be demonstrated at
Technical Inspection.
Teams must have a method to demonstrate that the actions in IC.4.7.2.b above are met.
System states displayed using calibration software must be accompanied by a detailed
explanation of the control system.

Team Members and Supporters
IC.6.2.1  Individuals who are not team members may attend a dynamic event for the purpose of:
a. Demonstrating a prototype
b. Conducting a presentation
c. Answering questions
d. Attending a meeting
e. Participating in a press conference
The organizer must be convinced that the presence of these individuals will not influence the
decisions of the dynamic event officials.
a. Each organization must submit a detailed explanation for any such visit.
b. The visit may or may not be allowed, depending on the judgment of the dynamic event officials.
c. If allowed, the visit will be limited in time and duration.  
The decision will depend on the specific visit and the judgments of the dynamic event officials.  
AD.3.3.4  Driving by individuals other than the drivers specified in AD.3.2.3  is prohibited at any time  
during the Dynamic Event.
Formula SAE ® Rules 202 4 © SAE International   Page 10 of 140
ground_truth:
Definitions
a. High Pressure fuel systems - those functioning at 10 Bar pressure or above
b. Direct Injection fuel systems - where the injection occurs directly into the combustion
system
Direct Injection systems often utilize a low pressure electric fuel pump and high pressure
mechanical “boost” pump driven off the engine.
c. High Pressure Fuel Lines - those between the boost pump and injectors
d. Low Pressure Fuel Lines - from the electric supply pump to the boost pump

ground_truth:
All High Pressure Fuel Lines must:
a. Be stainless steel rigid line or Aeroquip FC807 smooth bore PTFE hose with stainless steel
reinforcement and visible Nomex tracer yarn. Equivalent products may be used with
prior approval.
b. Not incorporate elastomeric seals
c. Be rigidly connected every 100 mm by mechanical fasteners to structural engine
components such as cylinder heads or block

ground_truth:
Fuel rail mounting requirements:
a. The fuel rail must be securely attached to the engine block or cylinder head with brackets
and mechanical fasteners. Hose clamps, plastic ties, or safety wires do not meet this
requirement.
b. The fastening method must be sufficient to hold the fuel rail in place with the maximum
regulated pressure acting on the injector internals and neglecting any assistance from
cylinder pressure acting on the injector tip.
c. Threaded fasteners used to secure the fuel rail are Critical Fasteners, see T.8.2

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule EV.5.2.2 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.

ground_truth:
If the Accumulator Container is made from an electrically conductive material:
a. The poles of the Accumulator Segment(s) and/or cells must be isolated from the inner
wall of the Accumulator Container with an insulating material that is rated for the
maximum Tractive System voltage.
b. All conductive surfaces on the outside of the Accumulator Container must have a low
resistance connection to the GLV System Ground, see EV.6.7
c. Any conductive penetrations, such as mounting hardware, must be protected against
puncturing the insulating barrier.

ground_truth:
Each Accumulator Segment must be electrically insulated with suitable Nonflammable
Material (F.1.18) (not air) for the two:
a. Between the segments in the container
b. On top of the segment
The intent is to prevent arc flashes caused by inter segment contact or by parts/tools
accidentally falling into the container during maintenance for example.

ground_truth:
The Intermediate Circuit must precharge before closing the second AIR. The end of precharge
must be controlled by one of the following two options:
a. Feedback by monitoring the voltage in the Intermediate Circuit
b. A conservative time defined by the longer of:
• Twice the time to charge to 90%
• The time to charge to 90% plus 500ms

EV.1  EV DEFINITION

ground_truth:
The Tractive System must contain a Discharge Circuit. The Discharge Circuit must be:
a. Wired in a way that it is always active when the Shutdown Circuit is open
b. Able to discharge the Intermediate Circuit capacitors if the HVD has been opened
c. Not be fused
d. Designed to handle the maximum Tractive System voltage for minimum 15 seconds

any electrical component that it protects

used when all three conditions are met:
• An Overcurrent Protection device rated at less than or equal to one third the sum of the
parallel fusible links and complying with EV.6.6.2.b above is connected in series.
• The AMS can detect an open fusible link and will Open the Shutdown Circuit EV.7.2.2 if a
fault is detected.
• Fusible link current rating is specified in manufacturer’s data or suitable test data is
provided.

c. On the positive conductor in the Grounded Low Voltage System

ground_truth:
Grounded parts of the vehicle must have a resistance to GLV System Ground less than the
values specified below.
a. Electrically conductive parts 300 mOhms (measured with a current of 1 A)
Examples: parts made of steel, (anodized) aluminum, any other metal parts
b. Parts which may become electrically conductive 5 Ohm
Example: carbon fiber parts
Carbon fiber parts may need special measures such as using copper mesh or similar to
keep the ground resistance below 5 Ohms.

ground_truth:

• Demand for Hard Braking EV.4.6

The BSPD may delay opening the shutdown circuit up to 0.5 sec to avoid false trips

ground_truth:
The team must have a test to demonstrate BSPD operation at Electrical Technical Inspection.
a. Power must not be sent to the Motor(s) of the vehicle during the test
b. The test must prove the function of the complete BSPD in the vehicle, including the
current sensor
The suggested test would introduce a current by a separate wire from an external power
supply simulating the Tractive System current while pressing the brake pedal

ground_truth:
Once the vehicle receives Inspection Approval, the ONLY modifications permitted to the
vehicle are the following:
• Adjustment of belts, chains and clutches
• Adjustment of brake bias
• Adjustment to engine / powertrain operating parameters, including fuel mixture and
ignition timing, and any software calibration changes
• Adjustment of the suspension
• Changing springs, sway bars and shims in the suspension
• Adjustment of Tire Pressure, subject to V.4.3.4
• Adjustment of wing or wing element(s) angle, but not the location T.7.1
• Replenishment of fluids
• Replacement of worn tires or brake pads. Replacement tires and brake pads must be
identical in material/composition/size to those presented and approved at Technical
Inspection.
• Changing of wheels and tires for weather conditions D.6
• Recharging Low Voltage batteries
• Recharging High Voltage Accumulators

model_prediction: 30 minutes before the start of the Dynamic Event, the Dynamic Event Officer will conduct an Inspection of the Dynamic Event Area.
ground_truth:
Penalty Method A - Fixed Point Deductions
a. From the Bill of Material, the Cost Judges will determine if all Parts and Processes have
been included in the analysis.
b. In the case of any omission or error a penalty proportional to the BOM level of the error
will be imposed:
• Missing/inaccurate Material, Process, Fastener 1 point
• Missing/inaccurate Part 3 point
• Missing/inaccurate Assembly 5 point
c. Each of the penalties listed above supersedes the previous penalty.
Example - if a point deduction is given for a missing Assembly, the missing Parts are ignored.
d. Differences other than those listed above will be deducted at the discretion of the Cost
Judges.

question: We are a student engineering team designing a vehicle for the FSAE competition. Attached is the FSAE rules document. What does rule S.3.12.5 state exactly? Answer with only the text of the rule and no other words.
model_prediction:
3.12.6: The organizer may provide additional guidance or reference documents for the cost estimate.
    3.12.7: The cost estimate must be performed using the cost estimate template provided by the organizer.
    3.12.8: The cost estimate must be submitted as a single PDF document.
    3.12.9: The cost estimate will be evaluated based on accuracy and completeness.
    3.13 ELECTRICAL SYSTEM DESIGN  
Electrical System Design will be evaluated on the basis of: • High Power Drives • Control and 
Monitoring • Protection and Shutdown • Integration • Maintenance Access • Noise and Vibration 
• Electromagnetic Compatibility (EMC)
ground_truth:
Penalty Method B – Adjusted Cost Additions
a. The table cost for the missing or incomplete items will be calculated from the standard
Cost Tables.
b. The penalty will be a value equal to twice the difference between the team cost and the
correct cost for all items in error.
Penalty = 2 x (Table Cost – Team Reported Cost)
The table costs of all items in error are included in the calculation. A missing Assembly would
include the price of all Parts, Materials, Processes and Fasteners making up the Assembly.

f. Immediately upon finishing the fourth lap, the vehicle will exit the track. The exit is at the
intersection moving in the same direction as entered

a. Vehicle will stop in Driver Change Area

time stops.

i. The vehicle stages to go back onto course, at the direction of the event officials

passing zone exit flag.

Scoring Term Definitions:
• Endurance Run Time - Total Time for both Drivers, minus the Driver Change lap, minus
any Mechanical Black Flag Time, plus any Penalty time D.14.2
• Corrected Time = Endurance Run Time + ( DOO * 2 ) + ( OC * 20 )
• Tyour - the Corrected Time for the team
• Tmin - the lowest Corrected Time recorded for any team
• Tmax - 145% of Tmin

a. Accurate and complete information in the report
b. Clear and concise writing
c. Appropriate use of visual aids
d. Proper citation of sources
e. Proper use of team members’ names
f. Proper use of abbreviations and symbols
g. Proper use of visual aids such as diagrams, charts, graphs, and photographs
h. Proper use of engineering drawings
i. Proper use of other visual aids such as videos or presentations
j. Proper use of team communication
k. Proper use of Faculty Advisor’s name and contact information
l. Proper use of other team members’ names and contact information
